message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs and symptoms of meningitis (fever, poor feeding, lethargy, bulging fontanelle, and tensing of extensor muscles), which is a medical emergency. The most common causes of meningitis in neonates are Group B Streptococcus, Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes, and the best initial therapy is a combination of ampicillin (which covers Listeria) and aminoglycoside antibiotics such as gentamicin (which covers Group B Streptococcus and E. coli). Therefore, option (A) is the most appropriate choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with respiratory distress and fever, which suggests a possible bacterial infection. The history of premature rupture of membranes also increases the risk of infection. Ampicillin and gentamicin are the standard empiric treatment for neonatal sepsis until the results of CSF analysis are available. The other options are not standard treatments for neonatal sepsis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with respiratory distress and fever, which could be indicative of sepsis or meningitis. The bulging anterior fontanelle and tensing of extensor muscles suggest increased intracranial pressure. Pending results from CSF analysis, the best course of treatment would be a combination of ampicillin and gentamicin to cover for possible bacterial infections. Option B is also a possibility, but gentamicin is preferred over cefotaxime for coverage against gram-negative bacteria. Options C and D are not recommended for treating sepsis or meningitis in newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests bacterial meningitis, which can cause respiratory distress, fever, poor feeding, lethargy, and bulging anterior fontanelle. The best empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis in neonates is ampicillin and gentamicin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest possible meningitis, so treatment with antibiotics is necessary. Ampicillin and gentamicin are the first-line antibiotics for meningitis in neonates until the causative organism is identified. Other antibiotic options are not the standard for treating neonatal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn is presenting with signs of sepsis, including respiratory distress, fever, poor feeding, lethargy, and a bulging anterior fontanelle. The best initial treatment is empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics such as ampicillin and gentamicin while awaiting CSF analysis to confirm the diagnosis and tailor the antibiotic regimen accordingly. Options B, C, and D are not appropriate initial treatment for a suspected sepsis case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest meningitis. Ampicillin and gentamicin are the recommended treatments for neonatal meningitis. CSF analysis will confirm the diagnosis and guide further therapy if needed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with respiratory distress, fever, poor feeding, and lethargy, which are suggestive of neonatal sepsis. The bulging anterior fontanelle and tensing of extensor muscles are signs of increased intracranial pressure, which could be caused by meningitis or encephalitis. Ampicillin and gentamicin provide broad-spectrum coverage for common bacterial pathogens that cause neonatal sepsis, including Group B Streptococcus and E. coli, and gentamicin can also treat meningitis. Pending CSF analysis, the addition of other antibiotics may be considered.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with respiratory distress, fever, poor feeding, and lethargy, which suggest sepsis or meningitis. The bulging anterior fontanelle and tensing of the extensor muscles indicate increased intracranial pressure. Therefore, the best course of treatment would be empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Ampicillin and Gentamicin to cover gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria until the results of CSF analysis are available. Option B is also a reasonable choice, but Gentamicin has broader coverage than cefotaxime.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest neonatal sepsis, which is treated with ampicillin and gentamicin. The lumbar puncture will provide more information on the causative organism and may lead to adjustments in antibiotics.
